Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
12/3/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager at 517 -243 – 9743.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
• (b) A copy of the job description for the staff
member's current position.
Five of seven personnel files reviewed did not have a copy of the job description for
their positions.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (4) An agency shall maintain an orientation and
training record for staff members.
Five of seven personnel files did not have an orientation and training record for the
staff in their personnel files.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
2

• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:
• (c) Dates and places of contacts, names of
persons interviewed, and names of the
interviewers. If children are interviewed,
their last names may not be included in the
report.
One of two special evaluation reports reviewed included the youth’s whole name in
the special evaluation report.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following in
the child's record before a change of placement
occurs:
• (g) Information about the child was shared
with the new placement, consistent with the
requirements of R 400.12417.
One of eight case files reviewed did not have a change of placement document
consistent with the rule requirements.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (a) Within 30 calendar days from removal
from the home.
One of eight case records reviewed initial service plan was twelve days late from the
due date.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
3

Three of eight updated service plans case files reviewed were late and pass the 90
days requirement for the rule.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/1/2023 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 10/12/23
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Rule 400.12418 (5) Development of service plans. This rule states an agency
shall involve the child’s parent or parents in the development of service plans
to enable the parent or parent’s and foster parents to understand the plan and
to make sure this is occurring with each service plans. The agency is to ensure
this is occurring on a consistent basis.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance:
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: One CAP
submitted was in response to the 2023 renewal inspection completed on
10/1/2023 and the CAP was approved on 10/12/2023. The agency was cited for 6
violations, Rules 400.12418 (2) (b), 400.12509 (3) (o), 400.12510 (2), and Policy
FOM 722.08B, Policy FOM 722.08D and 801.03. There was one repeat violation
during this reporting period.
4

Chief Administrator Assessment:
Chief Administrator (CA) discussed barriers via team meeting that impeded the
agency this year. CA reported that stabilization of teams has been a priority and
staff turnover continued to be a challenge. CA reported significant efforts have
been made to ensure that internal procedures result in improved compliance. She
reported frequent and sudden turnover continues to present ongoing challenges
with consistency. She reported when staff exit with a 30-day notice, there is still a
significant gap in case coverage due to the increased time and efforts it takes to
recruit, hire, and train a new case worker while covering cases and trying to meet
the increased demands from the state. CA discussed that hiring has become
more difficult as there are jobs with similar pay ranges that do not require degrees
and does not have the stress associated with child welfare work. She said
retention of foster care case managers continues to be a strong focus for the
organization and their programs. The CA also discussed the increased emails
from multiple sources demanding responses back on data and information. She
said the Program Managers time and attention are pulled from supporting
supervisors and workers to managing data and responses. She said overall, the
agency is trying to comply with demands.
Financial Overview:
The agency submitted their agency budget and independent audit dated
12/31/2023. No concerns were noted.
Staff and Youth Interviews:
Three staff were interviewed via face to face on 10/10/2024. The staff interviewed
reported the agency is going through a transition period and the staff are feeling
anxious about job security. The staff stated the agency is disorganized at this time
and the new workers are lacking with agency trainings. Overall, the staff reported
they get support from their coworkers and their supervisors when the supervisors
are available.
Description of Agency Walk Through:
The agency has the space and equipment needed to perform job requirements.
The files are stored securely to prevent unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
DCWL Analyst identified one safety concern:
Safety Alert: Dated 9/16/2024, reported the breakfast nook where children eat was
observed with an open hole in the ceiling with exposed plumbing. The paint/ceiling in
the foster home is peeling in one of the bedrooms and there was water observed in
5

the basement.
Resolution: The agency opened a special evaluation # 2024SEC0001947, dated
9/27/2024, on the foster home and submitted photos of the foster home repairs of all
areas that were in concern. Photos were attached to the safety alert showing foster
home repairs. Photos were uploaded in CWLM.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
